report_title: Fruit and Vegetable Wholesaling Industry Report
executive_summary: The Fruit and Vegetable Wholesaling industry has experienced moderate revenue growth over the past five years. Wholesalers engaged in the distribution of fresh fruits and vegetables. Revenue is dependent on the market prices of fruits and vegetables in addition to the ability of consumers to spend their incomes at grocery stores and restaurants. Increased per capita disposable income has permitted consumers to purchase more fresh produce from grocery stores and visit restaurants more frequently. Consequentially, demand from downstream industries has grown for much of the period, driving revenue growth for wholesalers. As the economy has reopened, this industry has bounced back significantly, resulting in revenue growing at a CAGR of 4.5% through the end of 2024 to $143.7 billion, including a growth of 19.1% in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Product Prices Have Sustained Revenue, But Have Isolated Consumers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As a result of decreased crop output stemming from unfavorable weather conditions, fruit and vegetable prices have swelled over the past five years. Price hikes in fruits and vegetables have helped outweigh declines in per capita consumption as wholesalers benefit from selling goods at a higher rate to downstream buyers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Competition Has Led to Innovation
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Wholesalers have worked to increase the speed of acquiring produce, which has resulted in fresher fruits and vegetables for grocery stores. Fruit and vegetable wholesalers have expanded their customer service capabilities to include additional functions, such as ripening, sizing, repacking, consumer packaging and suggesting advertising for retail customers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Interest Rates Have Placed Strain on Consumers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Due to high interest rates compounded by rising living costs, consumers face significant financial hardships. This has directly impacted their purchasing capacity, particularly affecting downstream markets. These markets are finding it increasingly difficult to procure fresh produce as its prices soar alarmingly, placing essential healthy food options out of reach for many.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Increasing Demand for Organic and Locally Sourced Produce
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: To cater to the growing consumer demand for organic and locally sourced fruits and vegetables, wholesalers are expanding their product lines.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Ecological Concerns Will Lead to Innovation
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In the face of volatile weather and emerging disease patterns, crop production costs have soared, pushing farmers towards innovative solutions. As climate change continues to pose a significant threat, adopting new farming techniques and technologies has become essential for securing food production and mitigating the escalating expenses.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: International Tensions Will Upset Vegetable Prices
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Amid the ongoing Ukraine-Russia conflict, fertilizer prices are poised to soar, partly due to Russia's significant role as one of the world's largest fertilizer producers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Industry Will Continue to Consolidate
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consolidation in the food retailing subsector gives large retailers significant power in negotiating terms of sale with wholesalers. Retailers, including Walmart and Albertsons, have started to invest in vertical farming, a farming practice that involves layers of plants stacked on top of each other in a controlled environment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Wholesalers Are Pioneering Sustainability in the Supply Chain
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Wholesalers are shifting towards sustainable packaging options and adopting greener transportation methods to minimize environmental impact. There is a noticeable trend of consumers favoring wholesalers, prioritizing ecological responsibility and influencing purchasing decisions.

industry_definition: Industry operators wholesale a range of fresh fruits and vegetables to supermarkets, delis, restaurants, cafes and institutions such as hospitals.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level low - steady

threats: Per capita fruit and vegetable consumption

key_trends: Internal competition has led to innovation. Innovations in maintaining produce freshness characterize internal competition. Also, labor-intensive produce preparation options like precut fruits and vegetables have become increasingly popular.

Frozen food wholesalers threaten the industry. Frozen food wholesale has attracted customers who would otherwise buy fresh produce. Frozen produce is cheaper and specially prepared to last longer than its fresh counterparts.

Technological advancements have enhanced supply chain efficiency and transparency. These technologies allow wholesalers to optimize inventory management, reduce waste and ensure product freshness, boosting operational efficiency and consumer trust.

Increased competition leads to innovation. Leading wholesalers have made considerable strides to deliver fresher produce to consumers. In recent years, refrigeration, packaging and preparation innovations have shaped the industry.

Industry leaders have diverse options. Leading wholesalers offer much more than just fruits and vegetables. Sysco and US Foods, the two most prominent companies in the industry, also wholesale meats, frozen foods and spices.
US Foods is acquiring smaller wholesalers and industry-adjacent companies. This vertical integration strategy aims to cut costs and strengthen its position in the wholesale industry.

The industry is beset by heavy regulation at the federal and state levels. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) outlines standards for growing, transporting and selling produce that wholesalers must adhere to.

Industry assistance is reliant on private associations. Wholesalers do not receive much help from government bodies. Instead, assistance is found in private associations catering to general wholesalers.

Per capita disposable income dictates demand. At the same time, fresh fruit and vegetables are not strictly discretionary purchases but have increasingly become a cautious commodity. Frozen produce is inexpensive and more appealing to consumers on a budget.
Purchases are the most significant industry expense. Over the past five years, the volatile prices of fresh fruit and vegetables have made profitability difficult.
Wages rise with employment and inflation. With increasing employment, wholesalers have hired more laborers to fulfill demand for industry innovations like precut and packaged produce.

Coastal states play a crucial role in industry exports. California is a significant center of the wholesale industry because of its proximity to Mexico, a key importer of goods from the United States.
The Southeast region remains constant. Florida leads the Southeast because of its proximity to the Caribbean. The local production of oranges also attracts wholesalers.

Fruit sales continue to support the wholesale industry. Apples and bananas are the most popular fruits, and innovations in the produce production industry and globalization have allowed the sale of these goods year-round.

Wholesalers play a crucial role in the fruit and vegetable industry. They enable trade and cater to smaller wholesalers, often focusing on specific products and acquiring them from larger wholesalers.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Retailers are the largest market in the fruit and vegetable wholesale industry. Retailers include grocery stores, variety stores, chains such as CVS and 7-Eleven and large superstores such as Walmart or Costco.
These include restaurants, cafeterias, catering services and other establishments that prepare and serve food outside the home.

Hospitals and hotels regularly purchase large stocks of industry items, but they do not have the same bargaining power as some large retailers. Consequentially, wholesalers perform an essential function by procuring, packaging and delivering fruits and vegetables to these establishments.

Wholesalers often trade among themselves and larger wholesalers tend to sell to smaller ones. Some wholesalers specialize in certain niche fruits or vegetables and procure them from larger wholesalers that buy a wide range of products.

products_and_services.product_description: This category includes onions, lettuce, celery, potatoes, cabbage, asparagus, carrots and other vegetables.
Common fruits such as bananas, apples, watermelons, grapes, berries and peaches buoy revenue from this segment.
This segment also includes items such as grocery specialties and canned nonperishable products.

tier_1_suppliers: Fruit & Nut Farming in the US
Orange & Citrus Groves in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Water Supply & Irrigation Systems in the US
Tractors & Agricultural Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Supermarkets & Grocery Stores in the US
Fruit & Vegetable Markets in the US
Single Location Full-Service Restaurants in the US
Food Service Contractors in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Per Capita Fruit and Vegetable Consumption
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Increases in per capita fruit and vegetable consumption support demand for fruits and vegetables at the retail level, thus increasing demand for produce at the wholesale level. Increasing awareness of nutritional benefits leads health-conscious consumers to expand their daily consumption of fruits and vegetables, which drives revenue up to the wholesale level. A decline in Per-capita fruit and vegetable consumption poses a potential threat to the industry.

business_locations.location_description: The Western United States, particularly California, serves as a key agricultural center. It generates a substantial share of the country's fruits and vegetables. The West's ideal growing conditions and proximity to major urban centers sustain numerous wholesale businesses. The region's closeness to major urban centers such as Los Angeles and San Francisco offers wholesalers a substantial customer base, fueling business expansion. The West is renowned for embracing advanced agricultural and supply chain technologies, enabling wholesalers to manage and distribute produce efficiently and attracting more businesses to the region.

The Southeast's warm climate enables year-round growing seasons, providing a consistent supply of fresh fruits and vegetables and sustaining numerous wholesaling operations. The region's diverse array of crops, including citrus fruits in Florida and peaches in Georgia, establishes a substantial market for wholesalers to meet consumer demands. Proximity to major transportation hubs and ports facilitates efficient distribution to domestic and international markets, attracting many wholesalers to the Southeast.

The Mid-Atlantic's central position between the Northeast and the South offers convenient access to major markets such as New York City, Philadelphia and Washington, DC, enabling efficient distribution. The region features fertile farmland that yields diverse fruits and vegetables, bolstering a robust local supply chain for wholesalers. Access to major ports such as Baltimore and New York boosts import and export opportunities, positioning the Mid-Atlantic as an ideal location for wholesalers involved in international trade.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Wholesalers in the US fruit and vegetable market are significantly affected by the Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act (PACA) of 1930. It governs transactions involving fresh and frozen produce to curb unfair trading practices.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) of 1938 plays a crucial role in ensuring consumer safety and product transparency within the US fruit and vegetable wholesale industry.

The National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) governs interactions between unions and private-sector employers, barring those in agriculture, government, airlines and railroads. It guarantees employees the right to organize and engage in collective bargaining.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Occupational Safety and Health Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Occupational Safety and Health Act (OSHA) ensures safe and healthful working conditions across public and private sectors. It mandates a hazard-free work environment, addressing risks such as toxic chemicals, excessive noise and unsanitary conditions.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Adhering to food safety regulations, such as the FDA's Food Safety Modernization Act, necessitates substantial investment in expertise and systems, posing a significant challenge for new entrants to meet rigorous legal requirements.

Significant initial investments in warehouse facilities, refrigeration systems and transportation infrastructure impose a considerable financial burden on new businesses, making it challenging to enter the market without substantial capital.

Creating a unique value proposition in a competitive market requires innovative product offerings and robust supplier relationships. This can be challenging for new entrants due to their lack of established networks and brand recognition.

basis_points.basis_title: Internal competition has led to innovation
basis_points.basis_description: Innovations in maintaining produce freshness characterize internal competition. Also, labor-intensive produce preparation options like precut fruits and vegetables have become increasingly popular.

basis_points.basis_title: Frozen food wholesalers threaten the industry
basis_points.basis_description: Frozen food wholesale has attracted customers who would otherwise buy fresh produce. Frozen produce is cheaper and specially prepared to last longer than its fresh counterparts.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Despite their dominance, the leading wholesalers, Sysco and US Foods, contribute a small percentage of the industry's revenue
concentration_points.concentration_description: Their catalog encompasses a broad spectrum beyond fruits and vegetables, including meats, frozen items and shelf-stable products, catering to diverse food industry needs beyond fresh produce.

Most fruit and vegetable wholesalers operate as non-employers, showcasing a landscape dominated by independent individuals who produce and directly sell their produce. Predominantly, they cater to local communities, providing their goods through various outlets, including farmers' markets, roadside stands, or minor, independent shops.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are by far the largest expense for the industry
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The industry mainly purchases fresh fruit and vegetables directly from growers. Purchase costs have increased thanks to the rising price of fruits and vegetables during this period.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages are a steady and significant cost for the industry
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Produce distribution requires labor to preserve its quality. As employment has grown, resulting from new companies entering the market, wages have slightly increased as a revenue share.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Despite this heavy reliance on capital, similar to most wholesaling industries, this industry has many labor-intensive roles. These roles include tracking inventory, taking orders, preparing purchase orders by weight, checking produce for abnormalities and transporting produce to its end user. For every $1.00 spent on wages, wholesalers typically spend $0.11 in capital investment in 2023.
Commercial purchases often require bulk production and packaging. As a result, wholesalers have focused on streamlining these processes to capitalize on economies of scale.

volatility_points.volatility_title: PRODUCT PRICE VOLATILITY HAS LITTLE EFFECT ON SALES VOLUME
volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue volatility remains moderate because fruits and vegetables are staple items. Even when prices fluctuate, consumption patterns show little change, demonstrating a consistent demand across various price points.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Rising Inflation Has Impeded Revenue Potential
volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue is closely tied to the health of the overall economy. Rising inflation has plagued consumers, forcing them to be more conservative in their food budgets. Disposable income and its influence on downstream demand have driven demand during this period.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: STREAMLINED PRODUCTION PROVES EFFECTIVE IN KEEPING EXPENSES DOWN
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Rising labor costs have incentivized wholesalers to innovate production techniques. Automation has proven reliable and cost-effective in keeping expenses down while improving efficiency.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: INNOVATION IN REFRIGERATION AND FUEL EFFICIENCY
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Innovation in refrigeration technology has allowed wholesalers to stockpile and deliver more products to consumers. Warehouses are now equipped with state-of-the-art climate control systems that limit humidity, keeping produce fresh for longer.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain a competitive edge in an industry with many competitors?
FAQs.answer: Fruit and vegetable wholesalers gain a competitive advantage by providing consumers with the freshest produce in the most timely fashion possible.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on any single market, major customer or other single revenue stream?
FAQs.answer: Fruit and vegetable wholesalers provide both types of produce fairly evenly, helping limit price volatility in any fruit or vegetable.

FAQs.question: How is volatility in demand because of economic conditions or seasonality managed?
FAQs.answer: Disposable income varying because of economic conditions leads consumers to demand produce in different quantities, leading to volatility in revenue for fruit and vegetable wholesalers. That being said, demand for industry products is relatively stable as industry products are staples in the American diet.

FAQs.question: How does your company negotiate favorable purchase costs with upstream suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Fruit and vegetable wholesalers gain favorable purchasing prices by consistently working with the same farmers and proving they can deliver their produce to consumers without damage.

FAQs.question: How do boosting digitalization at the business level and the growing popularity of online shopping impact your financial performance?
FAQs.answer: Boosting digitalization allows wholesalers to scale up their operations effectively, driving revenue by reaching a broader customer base and improving critical areas like inventory management and logistics. The popularity of online shopping has made it easier for consumers to purchase fruits and vegetables, which has led to expanded demand for fruit and vegetable wholesalers.

FAQs.question: How has your company been able to implement technology into the purchasing process to make the most efficient buying process for customers?
FAQs.answer: Fruit and vegetable wholesalers have implemented refrigerator systems to ensure produce remains fresh.

FAQs.question: Food product wholesalers are subject to wide-ranging regulations from the FDA and other government agencies. What is your company policy to ensure compliance with regulations?
FAQs.answer: Fruit and vegetable wholesalers follow stringent guidelines to ensure food is stored correctly and prepared before being sent to consumers to ensure quality and sanitation laws. Following these guidelines is crucial to maintain business.

FAQs.question: How does your company monitor potential future changes to the regulatory environment?
FAQs.answer: Fruit and vegetable wholesalers must remain vigilant to evolving regulation of their services including the licenses needed to wholesale fresh produce.

FAQs.question: How does input price volatility impact your purchase and selling costs?
FAQs.answer: Volatility in the cost of fruit and vegetables is difficult for fruit and vegetable wholesalers to control, leading purchase costs to vary yearly.

FAQs.question: How does your profit compare with your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: While profit for all fruit and vegetable wholesalers is relatively thin, profitability varies primarily based on the type and quality of produce wholesalers sell.

FAQs.question: What processes do you have in place to ensure prompt delivery to market? How could you improve in this regard?
FAQs.answer: The products of this industry are highly perishable. To maintain the fresh quality of produce, it's important that it's delivered promptly to its end-users.

FAQs.question: Do you have contracts with suppliers of your key inputs? How could you accumulate more contracts?
FAQs.answer: Disruptions in supply can drive existing customers away and damage a wholesaler's reputation.

FAQs.question: Do you invest in research and development? What are the associated costs?
FAQs.answer: Stable growth of food consumption results in introduction of value-added products like pre-cut fruit and ready-made salads. Fruit and vegetable wholesalers compete on this basis.

FAQs.question: Are you able to pass on price hikes to your consumers?
How closely do you track the price of fruit?
FAQs.answer: The price of fruit largely determines industry revenue because wholesalers can pass on price increases to downstream markets like grocery stores and fast food establishments. When the price of fruit drops, industry performance usually declines.

FAQs.question: How much of your demand comes from supermarkets and grocery stores? Do you have future plans to boost demand from this market?
FAQs.answer: Key downstream markets include supermarkets and grocery stores, which retail an increasing variety of fresh fruit and vegetable products. When demand from supermarkets and grocery stores increases, industry revenue increases.

FAQs.question: Do you target health-conscious consumers? How will you prepare for a decline in fruit and vegetable consumption?
FAQs.answer: Nutritionists advise that consumers incorporate three to five servings of fresh fruit and vegetables into their daily diets because of the health benefits of fresh produce. Health-conscious consumers following this advice demand more fruit and vegetables at the retail level.
